D. yf this be vnthank fullnes, we will yet be more vnthankfull. we acknowledge the wonderfull patience and longe ſuffering of our good and gratious God, in bearing with us hitherto; we magnifie the exceeding riches of his mercie, in viſitinge us, with ſo manie & merveilous deliuerances: we joie & rejoyce with ioye vnſpeakable in the glorious light of the goſpell, which (notwithſtanding the great ecclipſe ſoe lately made) ſhineth yet in manie places as cleare as the ſū at noone daie, the confortable light wherof, we eſteeme as the life of our life. Nether are we vnmindefull of Gods goodnes towards us in that outward peace and proſperity which we injoye vnder the gouerment of our dread ſovereigne, the breath of our noſtrels, vnder the ſhadowe of whoſe winges next vnder God, we aknowledge our lives preſerved amonge the heathen: we bleſſe God for him, & ſhall neuer ceaſe to ſaie God ſave the Kinge; what then? are we notwithſtanding vnthankfull, becauſe we deſire to drinke more plentifully, even our fill of the ſvveet cupp of theſe mercies and that God would fulfill all the good pleaſure of his goodnes upon us &
oue poſteritie? I trow not: eſt ingenui & liberalis animi, cui-multum debeas, ei plus veldebere: it is no vnthankfullnes to deſyre to be more indebted to him, to whom we owe much already. But ſee, hovv M. D. taxeth all the ſervants of God, high & lowe, from the begining of the vvourld almoſte, to this daie, vvith vnthankfullnes; if this be vnthankfullnes: vvould David lett the ark alone vvhere Saul his predeceſſour left it? did Salomon lett it reſt, vvhere David his Father left it? did not Ichoſaphat lifte up his heart to the vvaies of the Lord? took he not a vvaie the high places and groves from out of Iudah, and reformed he not more then his predeceſſours, yea more then Aſa his Father had done before him? did not Hezekiah throvv dovvne the high places, vvhich Iehoſaphat lefte ſtanding? did not Ioſias ouer turne many things, vvhich Hezekiah threvv not dovvne? vvhat ment the cheife Fathers and Ancients, Preiſts and Levites after their returne from captivity vvhen they ſavve the foundation of the temple layd, becauſe it vvas not anſvverable to the former; to vveep, I ſaie to vveepe vvhen others laughed for ioie? vvhy did Nehemia buyld the vvalles of Ieruſalem, perfit that vvhich Ezra began, and reformed the feaſt of Tabernacles better then all his predeceſſours hovv Godly and zealous ſo ever? vvherefore did the Lords prophets preſſe a further reformation upon the Kings follovving, vvhatſoeuer reformation their predeceſſors had made before them? vvhat ment they? vvere they all vnthankfull? Lett us come dovvne lovver; An non perfecit Conſtantinus quod Philippus ìam ceperat,
Ceſar Baraicus annal. An 227. did not Conſtantine perfit vvhat Philipp began; did not Theodoſius
Theod ore Hiſt. lib. 5. Ca. 20 goe forvvards vvith the reformation vvhere Conſtantine lefie? ſee the ſtoryes. To cōe lovver yet, vvhat vvill M. D. ſaie to thoſe vvorthey lights and glorious Martyrs? to Father Latimer? vvho reſted not vvith the reformation in K. Henrie the S. daies but parſvvaded K. Edvvard to a further; to Hooper and Bucer?
Bucer in cenſura Ca. 12 hovv not content vvith the firſt
purging of the leiturgie by K. Edward, gaue him not over till he had purifyed it the ſecond time, as the ſecond edition therof ſheweth: to our late ſovereigne Lady now bleſſed? who reformed diuerſe things lefte by her worthy brother; to Bb. Iewell, Bentham, Pilkinton & others? who never preſented omnia bene to her Magiſtie, as M. D. here doth to all the world, vvhere he ſaith, we have what is fitt for us, almost what we can deſire. Conclud, if vve be vnthanfull, are not all theſe? if dangerouſly vnthankfull; vvhat is M. D. himſelf? vvho in his ſermon before named, (vvhich I vviſh were read euery morning to our Bbs. next their hearts) contenteth not himſelf with the miniſtery amonge us as it novv ſlandeth, but cenſureth ſharplie & rightly, that ignorant idle & ſcandalous Miniſterie, vvhich poſſeſſeth agreat parte of the land, & vve dſyre maie poſſeſſe no parte of it. The truth is, that this crime of vnthankfullnes here caſt upō us, belongeth properly to others vvho are at eaſe in Sion, abondantly provided for, gorgiouſly clothed, fare deliciouſly, invent to themſelues inſtruments of delight, rovve in their barges, rid in their coches from houſe to houſe at pleaſure, think it time to repaire & buyld their ovvne hovvſes, to ſeele their chambers &c. more princelik then preiſtlik: and yet ſaie it is not time to buyld the Lors houſe, or repaire ought that is amiſſe therin, naie condemne them of dangerous vnthankfullnes, that vvill bringe one ſtone tovvards it, or ſo much as vviſhe vvell to it: doe you ſoe revvard the L. ye houſe of Iſraell?.

Thus as length are vve come to the ende of his fourth charge: in his fyfte, he accuſeth us, to grow wanton in religion, through ſpirituall pride, not caring for the heavenly foode of our ſoules, vnleſſe we maie have our owne ſauce, preferring the ceremonie and circumſtance of religion before the ſubſtance: vpon vvhoſe ſhoulders this taxe lieth heavieſt, theirs or ours, lett the vvorld judge: vve for our parts deſire
no ſauce of our ovvne, but vve utterly diſlike the popiſh Cookes, that have devyſed ſauces to make our religion ſavour and have a taſte vvith carnall appetites; and vve take no pleaſure in thoſe popiſh patchers, vvho marre our religious ſober & chaſte attire, and aſſaie to make her of a grave and ſober matrone, like a masking minion; and this vve count and that moſt juſtlie, ſpirituall prid and vvantonnes in religion. But to proue it, he chargeth 3. particulars upon us concerning the vvord, publik praier, and the ſacraments. In the firſt, he blameth us: firſt, for that we will not heare as he ſaith, a ſermon made at a funerall, be it neuer ſo proſitable; ſecondly, that by our good will we would heare none that is conformable, or if we doe, it is with preiudice, and making the word ineffectuall to us, we ſaye his gifts are decayed, his preaching is without power &c. both vvhich are meere ſlanders. Concerninge the former, the truth is, that many both Godly and learned, conſidering the originall of funerall ſermons from vvhence they cam; the ende for vvhich for the moſte parte they are novv obſerved, to vvit, the honor of the dead, and enriching of the preacher; and then hovv partially and vvith vvhat reſpect of parſons they are novv performed, for the riche not for the poore; & laſtly, hovv the preacher for his hire, as M. Dearing ſaith, in his ſermons on the hebrews. with a black mouth and a headlong tongue, bleſſeth the dead, calleth the niggard liberall; the eruell Nymrods and mightie hunters of the rightuous, myld and gentle parſonages, vvhoremongers and Adulterers, chaſte Ioſephs: popiſh ſuperſticious and profane parſons, true and religious goſpellers; and all this in their eates, vvho knovv they lie for advantage, and to pleaſe the frinds and kindred of the dead, vvhereby much offence often commeth to the hearers. Godly and learned men I ſaic conſidering theſe things,
it is no mervell they have no great affection to ſuch ſermons but to ſaie, they utterly refuſe to heare any be they never ſo profitable is a flatt vntruth. His ſecond is alſo a verie ſlander, as in parte hath already bin ſhewed, where the firſt breach thereof vvas handled; ſecondly vvhere he chargeth us, to heare thoſe that we doe heare with preiudice, he ſhevveth himſelf againe as ofte before, to be an in truder of himſelf into another mans cōſcience; thirdly vvhether vve or others make the word more vneffectuall to us: lett the effects ſhevve; fourthly yf any charge ſuch as have cōformed, with decaie of gifts, & loſse of the power of their miniſlery vniustly, I will not juſtifye thē in it: but they that have eyes to ſee, maie ſee it is too true, in too manie at this daie, & if they ſee it not thēſelues, it is their owne blindnes. But to paſſe by the like ſlāders in the reſt of thoſe vvords, lett us come to his 2 charge vvhich concerneth praier; vvhere he ſaith, that if lawe did not compell us, we had rather be at no publi
que praiers, then at thoſe ſeett forth by authority, or if we be preſent, we ioine not with the congregation. In deed, vvhere publique praiers are read by ſuch ſeely Curates, as can doe nothing but reade, & then alſo ſlubbred and poſted over, that they maie poſte to ſome other place for the like ſervice:
Heſra. 46. ſuch parſons being no preiſts to the Lord, nor performinge any ſervice in him and for him; it is not much to be cō demned in the forwarder ſort, that they are greived thereat, and joyne no further then lavve compelleth them. Nay I vvonder they can come to them at all; ſeing manie of the vulgar ſort, that have little ſavour of grace in them, diſtaſte both the Sayers & their ſervice, & vvould not joine vvith them, vvere they not cōpelled thervnto. But vvhere publique praier is read by any Miniſter of God, I perſvvad my ſelf, M. D. cannot make good this charge upon any one of them. Lett us therefore heare his 3 cenſure which concerneth the ſacraments vvhere he ſaith, we had rather, if we might chooſe, not have our childe baptized, then that the croſſe in baptiſme
should be uſed; and not receyve the communion, then receyve kneeling &c. For anſwere wherevnto, in generall, lett it be obſerved how againe he ſitteth in the conſcience of his brother & judgeth him to deſyre the ſacraments as they are now adminiſtred, not of conſcience to Gods ordinance; but onely to aveyd puniſhment; Secondly, concerninge baptiſme, lett him tell us, whether he himſelf that now yeldeth ſoe willing to the croſſe in baptiſme; would yeld as readily to oile, creame, ſalt, ſpittle & the ſetting on of the croſſ on the lipps, cies, care and aſwell as on the forhead? yf not? lett him not blame us then, yf we would not willinglie have our children croſſed, none of the other are more evill then this, as that learned treatiſſe of the ceremōies, ſheweth Scholasticall diſcourſeagainſt ſymbolizing with Antich. &c.. But that any vvould rather their children ſhould not be baptized at all, then croſſed, is vntrue, we have learned, that however the Miniſter ſinneth in making it, the parent that proteſteth againſt it, ſinneth not in deſyring the ſacrament, & for his credit ſake, lett him name us ſome fewe that keep their children vnbaptized becauſe of it. As for kneeling at the inſtant of receyving the bread and wine in the L. ſupper: ſeing it is ſoe ſufficiently proved to be vnlawfull both be fore and ſince this ſermon, by a certeine Diſpute of that ſubject. M. D. mought have forborne, & I hope will hereafter forbeare the raxing of us for refuſing it, eſpecially till that Diſpute be ſoundly an ſvvered & confuted. Thus much for the imputations laid upon al Chriſtians in generall, of the forwarder ſort as he calleth them. Now it followeth in particular of them that ſett forth the book in titled the Modeſt Ofer &c. whom he challengeth, to have publiſhed diverſe aſſertions which he calleth ſchiſmaticall novelties, new found affections, vndigeſled fancies, the principall wherof were neuer heard of in the Church of God aboue 1600 yeares after Chriſt, the which, yf they were established, would breed horrible confuſions, and yet ſo vehe mently urged by them, that ſeperation is to be made from all thoſe Churches
which admitt them not; and if they be not granted, they ſee not how our ſ • paration from the Church of Rome can be iustifyed, and doe offer that if the Preiſts and Ieſuites can ſatisfye them concerninge their propoſitions, they will be reconciled to the ſea of Rome &c. Theſe & ſuch like speaches chargeth he upon them, and in the laſt page challengeth all Godly & learned Miniſt, that proteſt not against them and diſſavow them, but ſuffer the people to receyve them. For anſwere wherunto, firſt this I maie ſay, that the publishers of thoſe aſſertions have hitherto (as appeareth by that their modeſt offer not yet accepted) bin more ready to prove them to be no ſuch ſchiſmaticall novelties, new found aſſertions, new undigeſted fancies, as he calleth them, then he or any of his ſide are, to make good this charge. Secondly, how confidently ſoever they avouch them; yet in the conſcience of M. D. himſelf & the reſt of his ſyde, (ſuch as are indifferēt at leſte) they are as farre (if not further) from joining with the Papiſts as ſome Prelates & their Proctors, utterly abhorring their abhominable idolatries, deteſtable hereſies, vaine devices & inventions, ſuperſtitions, rites & ceremonies ſtollen from Iewes or Gentiles, unfeynedly hateing that whore of Babylon, that ſea of Antichriſt, that mother of fornication, died read with the bloud of the Saints; yea deteſting head & taile, roote & branch of poperie, being in deed of the nomber, of thoſe (whom Bb. Bilſon
Cont. Apol. Sem. pa. 22. commendeth,) who are ſoe farr from admitting the full doze of Popish haereſies, that by no meanes they can diieſte one dram of their ceremonies; and of thoſe, who (as D. Fulk
Retent. againſt Briſtow pa. 98. ſaith) abhorre whatſoever hath but a shewe of poperie. Novv they being ſuch men in deed, and that in the conſciences of our adverſaries, though they in the cō ſcience of the truth of thoſe aſſertions, reſolutelie deliver, that if our Prelates can mainteine their dignities, preheminence & majorite of rule, vvhich novv they exerciſe over us, to be jure divino, and that there be Churches Dioceſan, Provinciall & nationall,
founded in the vvord: it vvill then follovv by as good reaſon, that there is a Church univerſall, and ſoe one univerſall Paſtor to be ſett over all; vvhich being the ordinance and inſtitution of God, is not to be rejected for the faults of men: M. D. might have ſpared theſe reproaches, & ſpent his ſpeach and pen much better, in ſhevving hovv the conſequence is not good, & that the one ought to be receyved, the other in no ſort to be admitted; ſoe had he done God & his Reader good ſervice, & his brethren the leſſe vvrōge, vvhich is ſoe much the greater, for that diverſe of theſe imputations vvere removed by their ovvne anſvvere in that modeſt offer
In their anſwere to the 11 oppoſitiō pag 38 & the reſte anſvvered by vvord of mouth before the high Commiſſion at Lambith, before M. D. eyther preached or printed this Sermon, yea the aſſertions themſelves proved in a former booke of M. H. I. for any anſvvere & proofe they have yet made to the contrarie.

As for his challenging of all them vvho diſſavovve not thoſe aſſertions, & proteſt not against them, I vvill onely aſke him, vvhat he meaneth to beate himſelf and the reſte of his ſyde ſoe ſoundly. It is vvell knovvne vvhat corrupt and unſound doctrines have bin lately preached & printed here in England, as that the ſcriptures cō teine not all thinges neceſſarie to be knovvne to ſalvation; that they are not the onely rule of all good and evill in the actions of men; that it is not to be inquired whether Chriſt be in the Sacrament by Conſubstantiation or Tranſubſtantiation, & that it can no waies hinder or further us however it ſtand. Whereof ſee M. Hooker
lib. 1. pa 88. lib. 2. pa 122. lib. 5 pa. 176.. That the keeping of one daie in ſeven is ceremoniall, & obſerved novv de iure humano onely, ſee D. Hovvſons ſerm. upon Pſ. 118, page 20. That Divorces are a thoro onely & not a vinculo, & that the innocent partie after divorce, maie not marry againe. Theſ. Edit. Oxon. Anno 1602. The vvhich (vvith manie more concerning Chriſts deſſention into hell; the ſtate of Infants that die unbaptized, & ſuch like) are not approved for Canonicall truthes; vvhy then doth MASTER DOCTOR,
yea and the Prelates and the reſte of their Chapleins, proteſt againſt them, diſſavowe them? Why are the people ſuffred to receyve them as oracles? Thus much for his ſecond heade and the ſeverall branches of it; lett us now examine the third, and both the exhortations in it. The firſt is to unitie and peace, layd downe in many words, the breife whereof is, that we would fynde arguments to reunite our ſelves, & yf the proofes he hath brought in his ſermon overweye our reaſons, we would ingeniouſly acknowledg the truth. And becauſe he thinks, that feare of diſcredit maie hinder it, he taketh it awaie by three reaſons; firſt, from the remembrance of mās comon frailty, which is ſubiect to over ſight: Secondly from the reverēd opinion worthily conceyved of M. Calvin, Beza and other Divines. Thirdly, from the conceite of the good effects of the Diſcipline deſired, & evill of the eſtablished; In this firſt exhortation I moſt willing joyne with him, and doe earneſtly praie him, and charge him in the L. as he will anſwere it at that laſt and dreadfull daie; that he would in deed ſeek the peace of Sion, and be as deſyrous to uſe meanes to reunite himſelf and the reſte to us, and the reformed Churches; as he hath bin in this Sermon overbuſy in ſeeking reaſons to disjoine himſelf and others from us, and them; and that he would weigh in the ballance of an unpartiall judgment the anſweres brought to his proofes, and if he fynde them to overweigh his reaſons, he would give glorie to God, by acknowledging ingenuouſly ſoe profitable, and as theſe tymes are, ſo neceſſarie a truth. And that according to his owne doctrine in his former Sermon, of the great neceſſity of the ſound and ſyncere preaching of the Goſpell, he would by all meanes labour, that it maie have free paſſage, that the people which periſh for want of knowledge, maie be taught the vvaie of ſalvation, that all true labourers in the word and doctrine, maie have the double honot he ſpeaketh of, & be cheerished as bees in the hyve; & that all Loy terers maie be chaſed from it as drones; that vaine titles maie not
anſwere for painfull offices & duties: that garments, complemēts & ſhadowes maie not be preſſed and preferred before ſubſtances, that the hearts of the rightuous maie be made no longer ſadd for vvelldoinge, nor the hands of the vvicked confermed & ſtrenghtned in evill. This is the ready waie to true peace & vnitie, by this meanes vve ſhall meet togither in one, vnited & revnited one to another: godlines vvill floriſh, athiſm & papiſme vvill be putt to flight, the popiſh hope & expectation of a change vvill be cruſhed, the mouthes that ſpeak proud things wilbe ſtopped, God vvilbe our God, our Sheild, our Buckler, our Caſtle and Defence, vve shalbe his people, & shall not need to feare any mallice of the adverſaryes hovv many, hovv mighty, how cruelly & malliciouſly, ſett & bent againſt us ſoever they be: much leſſe the feare of diſcre ditt he ſpeaketh of. Where becauſe as it ſeemeth, he judgeth of our eſtate, by the feeling he hath of his ovvne pulſt, it shall not be amiſſe to returne him home his ovvne reaſons vvith exchange of a fevv words: and therefore doe tell him, firſt he shall not need to feare diſcreditt, by making open acknovvledgment of his errors, diſcouered in this anſvvere & the hurt he hath done thereby: For the beſt maie erre, & it is a work of grace frō God & creditt vvith men to confeſſe them. Yf it vvere a diſcreditt: yet it shall be good for him vvith Ierom plus conſcienciae, quam nomini deferre, to reſpect his conſcience more then his creditt. The reverent opinion vve have vvorthily conceyved of thoſe vvorthy divines, hath moved us in deed the rather to imbrace the diſcipline vve ſtand for: & vve had good reaſon for it ſeing God hath bleſſed them ſoe exceeding abundantly, in all ſpirituall knovvledge and vnderſtanding, that (their & our aduerſaries being Iudges) they are found admirably ſound & orthodoxall in the ſubſtanciall pointes of religion. Yett have vve not ſoe relied upon their creditts, as not to ſearch into, & examine upon vvhat grounds they & vve ſtand as too manie of the other ſyd, vvho in their ſimplicitie (preſuminge upon the vviſdōe
and ſynceritie of the Bbs. whom they ſuppoſed would require nothing, but what they might ſafely yeld vnto) have relied on their creditts & putt to their hands & names, they knew not to what; that fault therefore which in this ſecond reaſon he extenuareth in us, is greater in them & had the more need be confeſſed by thē. As for the effects of both which in his 3. reaſon he ſpeaketh of, we muſt needs acknowledge they have had their effects vvith us.

The vnſpeakeable good, vvhich that diſcipline, that he calleth newe & vve olde & ancient, hath yelded to the Churches imbraceing it, the vvhich alſo, vve are perſvvaded, it vvill affoard us vvhenever vve receyve it, cannot but vvork effectually in us an earneſt deſyer & longing after it; as the manifold corruptions in doctrine & manners, taxes, troubles and vexations for vvell doing, vvhether ariſing from the perſonall defaults of the gouernours, or nature of the gouernment it ſelf; (not here to be diſputed of) but cleaving ſoe inſeperablie to it, that ſoe longe as the one remeineth vve cannot expecte any freedome from the other; hath made the Iſrael of God to grone vnto him for eaſe & deliuerance from it.

As for the horrible confuſions, vvhich vvould inevitably follovve if the diſcipline (as he ſarcaſtically calleth it) of the ne weſt edition vvere eſtabliſhed, vvhereby he vvould leſſen the corruptions of our tymes; as he ſpeaketh of that he knovveth not: ſoe vvhen he telleth us vvhat they are, he ſhall receyve his anſvvere. Thus much for his firſt exhortation, his ſecond follovveth, to vvit, that in cauſe his arguments in this ſermon, through our preiudice & partiallity ſeeme light to us, and we yeild not to them; that then our anſweres maie be diſtinctly applyed to euery argument in order, with pregnant & demonſtrative proofes, & then he will acknowledge his error, onely he deſyreth Chriſtian & modeſte dealinge, not ſuch as is in that book called, the Chriſtian & modeſt offer. Wherein, (to paſſe by the repeating of ſome things before ſpoken of, here againe mentioned, & namely the ſlander of Chriſt diſcipline, in ſaying it was neuer heard of till
now of late, & that our gouernment by Bbs. hath bin perpetually obſerued in the Church euer ſince the Apoſtles tymes, the falſhood of both vvhich pointes hath bin & ſhalbe at large diſcouered) vve have 3 things to be obſerved: firſt a diſyre of an anſvvere; 2. the conditions required; 3. a promyſe. Yf vve turne not vvith him, his deſyre is, vve vvould returne him an anſvvere, a diſtincte anſwer to all his arguments in order. So doe the Doctors of Oxford in their anſvvere to the petition of the 1000 Miniſters; ſo doth G. P. in his laſt book, vvhere he vndertaketh the anſvvering of all that can be ſayd in theſe cauſes. And M. Hooker in his preface before his firſt book of politikes, yea Bb. Barlovve himſelf preaching upon Acts 20 28 for the gouernment eſtabliſhed, much of the ſame that M. D. doth in this ſermon, in his epiſtle before it, profeſſeth that if there shall an anſvvere be made therevnto with modeſty and learning, nothing shalbe more wellcome, & that, to avouch & make it good; that the ſayd epiſcopall calling is vnlavvfull, were a labour worthy the traveil & much deſyred of the Bbs. All vvhich is done, if not by the appointment & commandment of the Bbs. themſelues; yet by their conſent & vvith their good allovvance, their bookes being ſeene & allovved, & ſome of them commended & commanded to be published, as they printe themſelues in their firſt pages. Wherein lett it be conſidered hovv injuriouſly vve are dealt vvith: firſt they deny us all meanes to publish our anſwers, taking from us the liberty of the preſſe, & punishing printer & thoſe whom they ſuſpect for authors, not ſparing thē that will not bettaie thē: whoſoeuer conſidereth theſe dealings maie juſtly ſuſpect, the Bbs & their Chapleines are combyned togither, the one to ſett ſnares & drawe us into them, the other to catch and crushe us: maie I not ſaie to them as Ierom
Hieron. Auguſt. Tom. 2. once ſayd, why are we blamed for writinge, is the fault in us or in your ſelues that provoke us, are we not compelled to defend our ſelues in our juſt proceedings? you have brought us to a fayre paſſe, yf we holde our peace, you holde us guilty; yf we anſwere, we are judged enemyes, as Ierom was, & punished for anſwering as Ietō was not. A hard condition of each ſyd, but of the two, we will chooſe the eaſyer,
rather then by ſilence to betraye the truth, by juſte apologie, what euer it coſte us, to mainteine it, yf you will have us to deſiſte from anſweringe; doe not you propound againſt us, laye you aſyde your ſwords, we will ſoone laie by our targetts: otherwiſe yf though you firſt provok us to ſpeak and then puniſh us; know you it is not the feare of puniſhment that shall fright us, the truth, which is the life of our life, is more deare vnto us. Thus much for his deſyre or challenge, his conditions followe and they are two. In the firſt he requireth that we diſtinctly apply our anſweres to euery of his arguments in order, with proofs pregnant and demonſtratyve. Which I acknowledge but reaſon; and had he dealt ſoe with us in his ſermon, we should have giuen him no anſwere: but his carrying awaie the matter in tryvmph, with diſcourſes, gueſſes, fancies, counterfeit writers, wittneſſes borne out of oue time, not old enough by 2 or 3 hundred yeares (ſome of them) to giue wittnes to his cauſe, his forced interpretations of ſcriptures and Fathers devyſed of purpos, and vvith great ſtreme of vvit, to putt by the truth, his equiuocations, frivolous and looſe collections, vvherof vve have good ſtore in his ſermon, (as their anſwere shall shevve) none of vvhich vvill beare a ſyllogiſme, nor abyd the hammering vpon the right anvyle: theſe courſes I ſaye can vve not allovv for proofes pregnant and demonſtratyve. As for this anſvvere, I referre it to the Reader to judge vvhether the demonſtrations therein, be not ſound, the proofes pregnant, and the arguments ſtrongely grounded upon the ſcripture, vvith plaine interpretations, & ſuch as have conſent, not of ſome fevve olde and nevve vvriters onely: but almoſt of all divines ſound and orthodoxall in all ſubſtanciall points of religion: yea admirable for their vvritings in queſtions tvvixt us and the papiſts. Diuerſe of vvhoſe anſvveres are applyed to M. D reaſons (vvhich he borrovved of the papiſts) and therefore not eaſely to be replyed to by him, nor departed from by us.
In his ſecond Condition, he requireth more Chriſtian and modeſt dealing, thē in that book called the Chriſtian & modeſt offer, which faith he, notwithstanding that title is full of odious Cenſures, proud & ſcornefull ſpeaches, vnchriſtiā & immodeſt provocations great bitternes & gall &c. Yf it ſhould be ſoe, which nether hath he ſhewed, nor can I acknowledge, yet lett the Chriſtian reader compare that their book, with this his preface, and I dout not but he will ſaie turpe est doctori &c. it is a foul fault in a teacher, to be deeplier guilty of the fault him ſelf, then the partie he blameth. I for my parte, when I read it, thought of the Philoſophers Diog. Laert: in Diogene cenſuring and checking of ſuch as offred ſacrifyce for health, and at their very ſacrifycing did banquet riotouſly againſt health: & of our regrators who have double waites & balances, ſome for buying & ſome for ſelling. The Lord giue us more charitie in our hearts then onely to upbrayd others with the want of it, & not feel our owne want in the practyce. Thus are we come to his promiſſe, that he will acknowledge his error, the which if it be aſwell performed as promyſed, we maie ſaie to him as Cyprian to Cornelius, though he miſſed of the firſt degree of happines, which is, not to offend; yet it ſhalbe well with him that he hath mett with the ſecond, vz. having donamiſſe to acknowledge it. And ſhalbe gladd to acknowledge him for none of thoſe, who convinced of error, bluſh not to ſaye, haud ſcio an iſta veraſunt, fortaſsis non multum abſunt a veris, ſed tamen libet ire contra. It maie be it is not vntrue that you ſaie: but yet I lik not to follovv it. I muſt goe againſt it. And to take M. D. by the hand, yf this anſwere ſatisfy him not, but ſhall ſeeme too light in compariſon of his ſermon, lett him laye open the vanitie & bring the inſufficiencie therof to light, I dare promis in the name of the reſte, we will (as Ierom ſayd to Cteſiphon) rather revoak our errors, then perſiſte in a wronge ſentence. And thus are we come to his 4. & laſte head: to wit, the concluſion with proteſtation: which
is, that what he hath deliuered either in his preface or ſermon, is that which in his conſcience he is verely perſwaded to be the truth. Wherevnto what ſhall I ſaie? I would rather have thought, he had this once done that, which many others have often done before him; & from the doing whereof the Fathers (as Ierom
Jerō: Apol: pro lib. contra Iovin; Cap: 4. noteth) thē ſelues in the heate of their contentions, were not alwaiſe free, non quod ſentiunt, ſed quod neceſſe eſt dicunt, aduerſus ea quae dicunt gentiles, that he had ſpoken, not what in his conſcience he thought to be the truth, but, quod neceſſe eſt dicere contra fratres, that which the cauſe he vndertooke neceſſarily drew him; to ſpeake againſt his brethren: but ſeing in charitie which beleeueth all things, I muſt herein credit him, I have no more to ſaye, but that his conſcience is blind, or was a ſleep when he wrote this ſermon, vvherein are contradictories, both which cannot be true. And ſoe with the lik proteſtation, & commendation of him to the grace of God, I end with the words of Cypriā to Florentius:
lib. 4 epiſt. 9. habes tu literas meas & ego tuas, in die judicij ante tribunal Chriſti vtraeque recitabuntur. I have your vvritings both ſermon & preface, you have my anſweres, (both according to the perſwaſion of our conſciences) & both to be recited before the tribunall of Chriſte. The Lord grant, that knowing that terror of the Lord, we ſoe perſwad men, as we maie approve our ſelues to God & the conſciences of his Children Amen.
